I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
loan  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  subprogram  2  of  the  Punjab  Millennium 
Development Goals Program. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
2.  Punjab is the most populous province of Pakistan (with 56% of the total population), 
with the largest provincial economic base in the country (accounting for more than 50% of 
Pakistan's gross domestic product). Yet its social indicators lag behind those of the other South 
Asian  countries.  This  is  particularly  true  for  two  important  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs), which Punjab will not be able to achieve by the targeted date of 2015 without wide-
ranging reforms in health service delivery and significant improvements in health care financing: 
MDG4, reducing the infant mortality rate (IMR), and MDG5, reducing the maternal mortality ratio 
(MMR). For instance, per capita public health spending in 2009 in Punjab was about $6.4, in 
contrast to the levels in 2004 of $18.1 in Bangladesh, $18.6 in Nepal and $74.1 in Sri Lanka. 
Such a situation has serious implications, given Punjab's importance to the country's economy. 
Recognizing the challenges, the Punjab government has attached top priority to the attainment 
of these two MDGs, and sought assistance from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to address 
the critical fiscal and health sector constraints standing in the way. 
 
3.  In response, during 2007-2008, ADB and the Punjab government together formulated 
the  program  cluster  comprising  three  subprograms.1 The  program  cluster  aims  to  improve 
access, quality, and equity of health services in the province, especially in relation to MDGs 4 
and 5. It will also more broadly ensure adequate health care for the poor by improving the 
availability and quality of primary and secondary health services, and developing a viable pro-
poor health care financing system. In addition, it will strengthen the management structure of 
health service delivery. 
 
4.  Subprogram 1 had several noteworthy achievements, including (i) creation of essential 
maternal, neonatal, and child health (MNCH) posts; (ii) recruitment of additional female health 
workers; (iii) mapping of private practitioners; (iv) strengthening of health information systems; 
and (v) merging of budget and development wings of the Punjab Health Department. By setting 
minimum service delivery standards (MSDS) in 2007, the government clearly shifted its focus 
from merely expanding to improving the quality of health services. Critical lessons from the 
implementation of subprogram 1 include the need for: (i) sustained and results-based interaction 
between the Health Department and the districts; and (ii) closer coordination with the provincial 
MNCH program to avoid duplication in the provision of equipment, drugs, and supplies.  
 
5.  Subprogram 2 continues to focus on MSDS implementation, particularly related to 
MNCH. Also, it seeks to improve day-to-day management of health services by addressing (i) 
capacity constraints in the health sector, (ii) challenges in recruiting and posting motivated 
doctors and other professionals in rural and remote areas, (iii) rigid administrative procedures, 
(iv) inefficient and lengthy procurement processes for drugs and medical supplies, and (v) lack

B.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the program will be the attainment of MDGs 4 and 5, relating to reducing 
the IMR and MMR in Punjab. The program's outcome will be improved access to, and quality 
and equity of, health services. The delivery of the minimum package of services described in the 
MSDS, especially for MNCH, is the core strategy for attaining MDGs 4 and 5. Therefore, the 
program focuses on reforms required for effective MSDS implementation. The program will 
assist the government in undertaking health sector reforms in three core policy areas (CPAs):  
(i) improve the availability and quality of primary and secondary health services, (ii) improve the 
management of health service delivery, and (iii) develop a sustainable and pro-poor health care 
financing system. A policy matrix for subprogram 2 and tentative policy actions for subprogram 
3 are in Appendix 4. Under each CPA, outcomes and outputs are identified to ensure sustained 
progress in achieving MDGs 4 and 5. 
 
C.  Outputs 
1.  CPA 1: Improve the Availability and Quality of Primary and Secondary 
Health Services  
a.  MSDS Introduced to Primary and Secondary Health Services 
7.  This policy objective aims to introduce service standards first in the public sector and 
ultimately to private sector health service providers. Under subprogram 2, the government has 
(i) completed a wide-ranging information campaign to build awareness of MNCH-related MSDS, 
targeting general public as well as health workers; (ii) ensured that each district government has 
updated  its  3-year  rolling  development  plan  previously  adopted  under  subprogram  1  for 
implementing MNCH-related MSDS; and (iii) ensured that seven district governments have 
substantially  conformed  to  the  minimum  level  of  MNCH-related  MSDS.  The  Office  of  the 
Director General, Health Services (ODGHS) is monitoring implementation of the 3-year plans 
through monthly meetings of the executive district officers for health. All 36 districts have signed 
a memorandum of understanding with the government to reach the minimum acceptable MSDS 
by 2012.  
 
b.  Primary and Secondary Health Services Fully Staffed and 
Equipped According to the MSDS 
8.  This policy objective aims to provide adequate physical and human resources to health 
facilities. Under subprogram 2, the government has placed at least one woman medical officer 
(WMO) or a lady health visitor or a trained midwife in 95% of the basic health units (BHUs), to 
provide the public with access to competent female staff for MNCH. However, the government 
faces difficulties in filling all existing vacancies of crucial MNCH-related positions, especially in 
the specialist categories, where 60% of posts for gynecologists are vacant and 48% of posts for 
anesthetists. A major reason for these high vacancy rates is the availability of attractive pay 
packages in the private sector and internationally. WMOs are crucial for delivering MNCH-

3 
related services, especially primary health care. Only 54% of WMO posts are currently filled in 
Punjab. The situation is comparatively better for lady health visitors (92% of positions filled) and 
nurses (75% of positions filled). For medical officers, 71% positions are filled both for primary 
and secondary care facilities.  
9.  Realizing the gravity of the situation, the government has developed a human resource 
plan to address these issues. It is also pursuing short- to medium-term measures, including ad 
hoc  recruitment  of  specialists  and  nurses,  accelerated  training  courses  especially  for 
anesthetists to bridge the gap, rotation of postgraduate training students from teaching hospitals 
to different districts, regularization of contractual posts (medical officers, WMOs, and nurses), 
age relaxation for hiring medical officers and WMOs, and introduction of evening shifts for 
training nurses in some districts to improve the supply situation. The Punjab Public Service 
Commission has recruited 1,200 medical officers (approximately 600 available for public sector 
service delivery) and 276 WMOs.  
 
10.  Availability of functional equipment is another essential feature of effective health care 
delivery.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  government  has  equipped  80%  of  BHUs,  rural  health 
centers, and MNCH-related departments of tehsil and district headquarters hospitals in line with 
95% or more of MSDS requirements. The government has developed and circulated a standard 
MNCH-related equipment list for all health care facilities, and circulated a pro forma to the 
districts for tracking the availability and functionality of equipment.  
 
c.  Measures Adopted to Improve Quality of Health Workers and Their 
Practices 
11.  The quality of health workers is the most critical determinant of the quality of health 
services, as paramedics, nurses, midwives, and lady health visitors play an important role in 
health service delivery. Five paramedical and 30 nursing schools are under the control of the 
district governments in Punjab. Under subprogram 1, a conceptual framework and plans were 
developed for improving facilities at these institutions. Building on this, the government has 
accomplished  the  following  under  subprogram  2:  (i)  improved  facilities  in  three  important 
paramedical schools and 15 nursing schools, through the provision of such items as minor civil 
works, teaching aids, computers, and books; (ii) trained 90% of the MNCH-related workers in 
the relevant parts of standard medical protocols, standard operating procedures, and referral 
protocols; (iii) approved a new service structure for paramedics; and (iv) introduced greater 
clarity and rigor in the profession, by separating the examination of paramedics from the Punjab 
Medical Faculty to the University of Health Sciences, known for its high standards, leaving the 
regulatory function with the former. 
 
12.  Continuous medical education is an important tool to ensure quality of health workers; 
however, in Pakistan, neither medical doctors nor paramedics have systematic opportunities or 
incentives to update their knowledge. The government has developed a continuing education 
system  for  both  groups  under  subprogram  2,  approved  by  the  chief  minister.  Continuous 
medical education will be linked to the promotion of medical and paramedical staff in the public 
sector in Punjab in the future, with implementation commencing under subprogram 3.  
 
13.  A comprehensive health human resources plan has been developed and approved 
under subprogram 2. The plan addresses both the quality and quantity of health sector human 
resources,  incentives  for  filling  vacancies,  rationalization  of  service  structures,  and 
computerized  registration  of  health  workers.  Further,  a  computerized  database  has  been 
established with detailed data of all health workers, including designation, place of posting, and

4 
addresses of the respective facilities. This will substantially improve the Health Department's 
mapping  of  human  resources,  besides  facilitating  the  process  of  postings,  transfers,  and 
promotions. Detailed information on all health sector staff will decrease the number of ghost 
workers, thereby increasing efficiency of health sector expenditures. 
 
14.  In Punjab, private health services are not subject to any regulation, which leads to 
widely varying quality. In some instances, private practices are run without a proper permit or 
registration. As a result, even identifying where private practitioners exist in Punjab is difficult. 
Yet, an estimated 70% of the initial health consultations are reported to take place at private 
facilities, including dispensaries. To protect citizens from negligence and questionable health 
practices, some regulation and quality oversight of the private sector is necessary. At the same 
time, private sector participation is vital given the capacity constraints in the public sector. 
Balancing these needs, the government has taken the bold step of introducing a health care 
commission, which would, inter alia, register private practitioners, license private health care 
facilities, and provide accreditation and performance audit of both public and private health 
facilities. The government will retain the role of standard setting. The proposed Health Care 
Commission Act has been presented to the Standing Committee of the Provincial Assembly and 
is likely to be approved as an act under subprogram 3, with an action plan developed for 
framing the required rules, bylaws and regulations.  
 
2.  CPA 2: Strengthen Management of Health Service Delivery 
a.  Improved Management and Performance Monitoring 
15.  Prior to subprogram 1, the role of ODGHS was reviewed from the perspective of the 
need to strengthen the management of health service delivery; ODGHS was subsequently 
restructured.  One  of  the  principal  functions  of  ODGHS  is  to  support  district  governments, 
especially with capacity development needs in planning and financial management. In this 
respect, the plan of action for district capacity development adopted under subprogram 1 has 
been fully implemented under subprogram 2. Specifically, 50% of the district health teams and 
managers  have  been  trained  under  subprogram  2.  As  noted  in  para.  7,  ODGHS  is  also 
responsible for ensuring the quality of the districts' 3-year rolling plans and the consistency of 
these plans with attaining the MSDS. Underpinning these efforts to monitor MSDS is the district 
health  information  system  (DHIS),  which  effectively  consolidates  various  sources  of  data, 
regularizes input, and promotes use of such information for decision-making. The DHIS was 
introduced in 10 districts in Punjab under subprogram 1. The government has rolled out the 
DHIS to all 36 districts under subprogram 2.  
 
16.  In  collaboration  with  the  Provincial  Information  and  Analysis  Unit,  the  Health 
Department is developing key performance indicators as part of an evaluation system based on 
transparent  criteria  for  assessing  the  performance  of  executive  district  officers  (EDOs)  for 
health, and medical superintendents for district headquarters hospitals and tehsil headquarters 
hospitals. The key performance indicators will provide top management with a tool for holding 
managers accountable for the effectiveness of field offices and service delivery outlets. Also, the 
government with the support of ADB has developed a results-based management framework 
covering eight line departments, including health. The framework will link public investments to 
development objectives through integration with the medium-term budget framework.  
b.  Improved Efficiency of Drug and Supply Procurement  
17.  This policy objective supports the achievement of the MSDS and reduced MMR and 
IMR by improving the procurement and supply system for the health sector to ensure necessary

5 
drugs and supplies are available on a regular basis, thereby eliminating frequent out-of-stock 
situations. Under subprogram 1, the Health Department reviewed drug, equipment, and supply 
management systems with a view to improving efficiency and transparency. Under subprogram 
2, work has progressed on sector-specific procurement guidelines, and 18 drugs have been 
identified as tracer drugs. These tracer drugs are tracked on a monthly basis through the DHIS, 
identifying the incidence and location of stock shortages. Additional monitoring of facilities is 
undertaken by the EDOs, health. While the tracer drug list is sufficient for primary health 
facilities, it needs to be expanded to reflect needs at secondary facilities. Under subprogram 3, 
the essential drug list will be rationalized for primary and secondary health facilities, preferably 
on the basis of burden of disease patterns within a specific district.  
 
c.  Alternative  Models  of  Health  Service  Delivery  Examined  and 
Institutionalized 
18.  Punjab has in the past implemented two models of contracting: with the Punjab Rural 
Support Program and the National Commission for Human Development (NCHD). In an effort to 
determine whether the contracting model produced better health outcomes and led to efficient 
and effective health services in the districts compared with those that did not contract, the 
government has finalized the study design for a third-party evaluation of the Punjab Rural 
Support Program and NCHD models with inputs from ADB and assistance from the United 
Nations' Children's Fund. Based on the evaluation results, where feasible, the government 
intends to move to institutionalizing viable contracting arrangements for the health sector. The 
government has also taken steps to improve efficiency of service delivery through functional 
integration of health services financed by federal, provincial, and district governments for the 
BHUs.  The  concept  of  functional  integration  was  finalized  under  subprogram  1.  Under 
subprogram 2, the integration approach was pilot tested in five districts in Punjab and the results 
appear quite promising. This will be rolled out to all districts under subprogram 3.  
 
3.  CPA 3: Establish a Sustainable Pro-Poor Health Financing Arrangement 
a.  Greater  Provision  and  More  Rational  Budget  Allocation  for  the 
Health  Sector,  especially  for  Primary  and  Secondary  Health 
Services 
19.  Under  subprogram  2,  the  government  has  developed  a  medium-term  budget 
framework for the health sector at the provincial level, which also captures local government 
activities, providing a consolidated approach to the health sector (provincial and district budget). 
In  this  context,  given  the  large  expenditure  requirements  and  low  levels  of  public  health 
spending, the government has increased the provincial budget for health by 15% in FY2010 
under subprogram 2. This will trigger an increase in district budgets and expenditures as well. 
 
20.  Analysis of district expenditure indicates that health services receive only a small 
share of the district budget and are severely underfinanced. To ensure that district governments 
allocate sufficient funding for MNCH-related MSDS, the conditional grant mechanism is used as 
a tool to earmark funds for the health sector. Under subprogram 1, grants were made available 
to all districts in Punjab. Under subprogram 2, those districts showing at least 80% utilization of 
their  first  grant  are  eligible  to  receive  the  next  conditional  grant.  The  grants  are  shown 
separately in the budget and are governed by a memorandum of understanding between the 
province  and  district  governments,  stipulating  access  conditions.  Under  subprogram  2, 
performance criteria have been incorporated in the second and third round of conditional grants

6 
to  incentivize  improved  district  performance  toward  achievement  of  MSDS.  A  designated 
secretariat within ODGHS will monitor district utilization of conditional grants. 
 
21.  Under subprogram 1, conditional grants in the amount of Rs.3.5 billion for pursuing 
MSDS were disbursed. Under subprogram 2, the government has allocated PRs 6.4 Billion ($75 
million) in the current FY2010 budget to be disbursed as conditional grants to those districts 
who  have  spent  80% of  the  conditional  grants  provided under  subprogram  1.  The  Health 
Department works with districts in ensuring they regularly report on the use of the conditional 
grants.   
 
b.  Improved Financial Management and Reporting, and Internal 
Controls and Audits in the Health Sector 
22.  Good financial management and reporting practices will help ensure effective and 
efficient use of resources to meet the program objective of improved quality and equitable 
access  to  health  services.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  Health  Department  merged  the 
Development Wing and Budget and Accounts Wing into the Financial Management Cell (FMC) 
to serve as the focal point for the Finance Department and the Planning and Development 
Department for provincial and district budget preparation, execution, and monitoring. The FMC 
bridges  the  traditional  separation  of  the  recurrent  and  development  budgets,  providing  an 
improved basis for resource allocation. Under subprogram 2, the budget classification codes 
have been amended to provide detailed monthly reporting for primary, secondary and tertiary 
health  care.2 Under  subprogram  3,  the  Health  Department  will  consolidate  reporting  on 
development and current expenditures in a manner that clearly sets out information on the 
implications of ongoing development programs for future recurrent spending. 
 
23.  While increased resources for the health sector in Punjab will help increase quality and 
access of health services, strong internal controls are vital to ensure that the resources are used 
effectively. Continuing earlier work, the government has taken a range of measures under 
subprogram 2: (i) clearance of more than 1,200 outstanding audit observations by the Internal 
Audit Wing; (ii) analysis of the effectiveness and adequacy of the present internal controls, and 
design of a conceptual framework for their improvement, guided by recent external audit reports 
for spending units within the Health Department; (iii) filling of the positions of director and deputy 
director of the Internal Audit Wing in the Health Department, separating the previously jointly 
administered  budget  and  internal  audit  wings,  and  setting  the  foundation  for  increased 
transparency  and  accountability;  (iv)  completion  of  a  fiduciary  risk  assessment,  which  will 
provide the basis for restructuring the internal control system, and an internal audit plan for 
implementation under subprogram 3; (v) development of a manual and training material for 
internal auditors; and (vi) appointment of internal auditors in 10 districts.  
 
c.  Pro-Poor Health Financing 
24.  The government is committed to increasing health investment and introducing major 
health financing reforms that will improve equity in access to health services and reduce the 
health expenditure burden. Major financing reforms may take several years to complete. Hence, 
the government has adopted a two-pronged approach: introducing short-term measures to 
relieve  the  poor  and  vulnerable  from  the  burden  of  significant  health  expenditure,  while 
developing an alternative overall health financing system for the medium to long term. Under

subprogram 2, the government pilot tested in two districts the Sehat Sahulat scheme, a pro-poor 
health financing model, which gives pregnant women living below poverty line access to free 
MNCH services through health vouchers. The results were evaluated and presented in a report. 
Based on this, and with a view to providing more institutional autonomy and efficiency, the 
government has rationalized user charges across facilities and according to services provided, 
and developed a mechanism for institutionalizing and retaining user charges for facilities. A 
conceptual framework for reducing health care expenditure burden on the poor was developed 
under subprogram 1. Building on this, the government has prepared a position paper over the 
course of 2009-2010. Based on the realities of Punjab's current health financing system, the 
paper presents various options for pro-poor health-financing: a tax based system, voluntary 
health insurance, social health insurance, and community-based insurance. While none of the 
options would be ideal on a stand alone basis for Punjab, the paper and background reports 
discuss the strengths of each and recommend that a combination of two or three of the options 
may be adopted. The position paper and recommendations have been disseminated within the 
health  community.  They  will  be  debated  at  a  round  table  for  major  stakeholders  under 
subprogram 3.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
27.  Subprogram 2 actions have been implemented over January 2009–June 2010. The 
subprogram 2 will remain open until 30 December 2010 to allow for the audit of the use of the 
counterpart funds generated from the loan proceeds. The management of subprogram 2 will be 
overseen by the Health Sector Reform Program Steering Committee, comprising the chairman 
of Punjab Planning and Development Board as the chair; and secretaries of health, finance and 
local  government  and  community  development  departments  as  members,  along  with 
representatives  of  various  public  and  private  sector  health  care  providers.  The  Health 
Department of the Punjab government will function as the executing agency, with Finance 
Department  and  the  Planning  and  Development  Department  acting  as  the  implementing 
agencies. The Health Sector Reform Program Management Unit, comprising 22 staff, will be in-
charge of the day-to-day implementation of the program.  
 
F.  Procurement and Disbursement 
28.  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding 
duties and taxes) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries excluding the items 
specified in a negative list of ineligible items. The list of ineligible items is a linked document 
cited in Appendix 2. The proceeds of the program loan will be disbursed in accordance with the 
provisions of ADB's Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for 
Program Loans.4 Loan proceeds will be disbursed for a broad range of imports on the basis of a 
certificate provided by the government stipulating that the value of the total imports of Pakistan, 
minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under 
other  official  development  assistance,  is  equal  to  or  greater  than  the  amount  of  the  loan 
expected to be disbursed during a particular year. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the 
loan proceeds and verify the accuracy of the government's certification. 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
29.  The provision of budget support for reforms under the Punjab Millennium Development 
Goals Program is justified on two principal grounds. First, as noted in para. 2, Punjab lags 
considerably behind other regions in South Asia. It needs to expand its public spending on 
health to catch up with its neighbors. Second, the district and local government interventions 
supported under the program are better implemented through a programmatic modality, given 
the reform imperatives to design and deliver basic health services for MNCH. The program 
supports  inclusive  growth  through  improvements  in  governance  and  service  delivery.  The 
reforms  will  improve  the  availability  of  health  care,  management  of  service  delivery,  and 
development  and  implementation  of  pro-poor  health  financing  arrangements  in  a  manner 
consistent with fiscal sustainability. The introduction of a medium-term framework for fiscal 
planning and a framework that consolidates recurrent and development spending objectives for 
the health sector ensures that increased financing for the health sector focuses on efficient 
spending  and  sustainability.  Conditional  grants  for  districts  not  only  contribute  increased

B.  Governance 
30.  Several governance risks are identified in the areas of public financial management, 
expenditure planning and control, procurement, and corruption. As a policy and institutional 
reform program, the program deliberately and explicitly puts governance and public expenditure 
management issues at the center of the reform effort. Reforms proposed under the program will 
positively  affect  the  current  institutional  setup  in  the  health  sector  and  address  these

C.  Poverty and Social 
31.  The majority of maternal and infant deaths in Punjab are preventable if women and 
children have timely access to quality preventive, primary, and secondary health care. Access is 
limited or delayed because health services are not physically available locally, doctors and/or 
medicines are not available, or services are unaffordable. Where health care services are 
available, their quality is not always optimal. Punjab’s health service delivery system needs 
quantitative and qualitative improvements, and measures to reduce the burden of health care 
expenditure on the poor. Poor people have the worst health outcomes and they are pushed 
further into poverty because of ill health, resulting in lower productivity or loss of daily wages, 
and a burden of high health care expenditures. Although public health care is in principle free, 
patients often have to pay substantial amounts for health care because of missing drugs and 
supplies at public health facilities. Approximately 75% of health expenditure is estimated to be 
financed through out-of-pocket expenditures in Punjab. Until 2 years ago, the majority of the 
health care budget of the government went to tertiary health care, which mainly serves the 
urban population and whose benefits are known to be regressively distributed.  
32.  Improved access and quality for primary and secondary health care supports a reduction 
in IMR and MMR consistent with the attainment of MDG targets by 2015. By that time, the 
program will have contributed to saving the lives of more than 11,000 women and more than 
235,000 infants. By assisting the government in implementing the MSDS, the program will 
ensure that the MSDS are observed and ultimately enforced throughout Punjab. The program 
will also improve the capacity of the Health Department and district governments in human 
resource management, and will support improved and ongoing training for all levels of medical 
staff. By ensuring primary and secondary health services meet the MSDS, the program will have 
a positive impact on MDG6, through inclusion of HIV prevention measures in the MSDS.
